review_title: Review for Controls Management Organization (CMO) team [formerly known as Oversight and Control (O&C)]
pros:
1 - Training portal has multiple courses to learn from
2 - Tuition Assistance Program (TAP) available to financially support employees to up-skill themselves through certified courses from various institutions
3 - Compensation is fairly good
4 - Free transport facility provided both to and from office premises (AC bus/cabs)
5 - Subsidized food rates and food card available for employees working in select shifts
6 - Internal job movement opportunities/portal available
cons:
Controls Management Organization (CMO) team [previously known as Oversight and Control (O&C)] at JP Morgan Chase:

JPMC is a great company, but CMO team is unfortunately not so good.

1 - CMO team is situated in an enclosed room, deliberately kept cut off from the rest of the teams/employees outside. It's a very small, cramped up enclosed area (max 16 seats), and also claustrophobic. The management deliberately does not want people outside this room to know what exactly is happening inside. Shouting loudly in the room and passing insulting comments to any team member is common. Abusive language is freely used to intimidate employees in this team.

2 - Senior Management members in this team are extremely arrogant and rude. They override firm-wide policies and create their own rules, thus misusing lack of knowledge of most employees. Senior management’s behavior is the major reason for the high employee attrition rate in this team.

3 - The firm has mandatory block leaves for employees at certain positions, who have access to some critical financial data. Hence, an employee has to take 10 days PL at a stretch and be off-work for that time.
However, in CMO team, management forces block leaves for the entire team, even though not a single employee has direct access to any financial data. CMO team is a support function under the corporate sector, and is not involved in company's financial data.

4 - Senior Management at CMO team forces team members to attend voluntary company events, irrespective of the employee's consent. CMO team employees are forcibly made to register and sign-up for events and if someone doesn't show up on that day, they are reprimanded heavily and threatened with dire consequences.

5 - Usually, when companies follow daylight saving, time in and time out for employees change by an hour or so.
However, in the CMO team, during the months of daylight saving, time in remains the same for all employees, only the time out gets extended by an hour. Hence, every year during the Daylight saving months, all employees in the CMO team are forced to put in extra work hours daily without receiving any monetary benefit for the same.

6 - JPMC provides food cards for employees who work in certain shifts which can be used to make purchases at the cafeteria. CMO team members work in 10 hour shifts daily during Daylight Saving months, but are still not allowed to avail this facility since all managers are strictly instructed by the senior management to reject all such requests from employees.

7 - Denims are included as part of business casuals, provided that they are not torn/ripped/distressed in any form. But in CMO team, the ED strictly instructed everyone to not follow firm-wide dress code policy, until further instructions from him. This behavior is still prevalent and unchecked in a brand like JP Morgan.

8 - Leave management is extremely bureaucratic in CMO team. Managers intrude employees' personal lives and demand to know reason for each and every leave an employee applies for. Although Planned Sick Leaves are allowed for the purpose of a surgery, managers in this team dissuade team members from availing such benefits which the company provides to all its employees.

9 - Employees in CMO team have to submit their entire year's planned leaves in advance. List of planned leaves for next year are to be submitted in Nov-Dec of current year. They make false claims to team members that these would be tentative dates and can be changed it later, if needed. But later in the year, if you want to change any PL date, employees are made to hear nasty things like they're being unprofessional.

10 - Managers and senior management deliberately avoid email communications with team members. Email requests for change in leave date, approval for Tuition Assistance Programme (TAP) offered to pursue courses/certifications which are sponsored by the firm, are blatantly disregarded without giving any valid reason for the refusal. Employees are intimidated and scared with harsh consequences and straight-away refused by managers to reply on the email requests.

11 - If you Google the term "People Skills", chances are that you'll come across certain soft skills like effective communication, listening skills, empathy, etc. which can help one elevate their career in an organization. However, in the Controls Management Organization team (CMO), "people skills" translates to "boss-pleasing skills"
Seniors in CMO team at JP Morgan cannot accept a difference of opinion or cannot take "No" for an answer.

12 - Favoritism is rampant in CMO team where managers choose their favorite employees and cover up or make excuses for the poor work of their incompetent favorites. They also tend to give their favorites better timelines and projects, more attention, and turn a blind eye to their shoddy work and lack of talent. If an employee blindly obeys management's orders, without questioning, he/she is showered with innumerable praises and accolades. Quality of deliverables, talent and hard work will be of no importance if you ever question the senior management or even suggest process changes.
Owing to this culture, team members feel discouraged to voice their opinions. Senior management is not open to accepting constructive feedback and suggestions for improvement.

13 - JPMC has ample opportunities for internal job mobility. In CMO team, once an employee informs their manager of mobility, they are treated very badly. Excessive work load, long working hours and all kinds of strategies are used to discourage the person from moving out of the team. There have been incidents when the senior management has refused to relieve employees who bagged internal opportunities and as a result, that position was given away to another candidate by the hiring team.

review_title: Satisfied, but there is room for improvement
pros:
1. When teams are cohesive, the work can be exciting and rewarding.
3. Immediate leadership is supportive and encourages self-development.
4. Job security; if you are in a business critical role.  There are many employees with 25 year tenures.
5. Interesting programs and opportunities for people who excel (the top 1%).
6. Information from management.  The senior management always gives an accurate account the current situation.  They never sugar-coat the situation; thereby making it easier to see pending job cuts or reorganizations are immanent.
cons:
Promotions are random and lateral moves are difficult.
- New people are at an advantage.  They are not tied into a particular function.  Therefore, they can go up the food chain easier.  To maintain business continuity, they will place new hires, instead of hiring within the firm, into lateral or new roles.  It makes it hard for existing employees to learn new skills or improve their standing within the firm.
Poor company sponsored development.  
- Only those who are on the edge get development/career advancement opportunities.  It is a carrot of sorts to preserve your position.  Otherwise, employees who work (normal people, not the 1% mentioned above) are considered too valuable to develop into new positions.  They are given the slow track to improve their careers.  This also explains the amount of employees who stay for 10 to 15 years in JPM.  It takes them that long to get into management or senior development roles.

pros:
1. Excellent infrastructure. Suffices to ask - how many global company in India have invested in desktop phones with video capabilities? Anyone in the organization, in any corner of the world, can call anyone else in the org, at his / her desk and start a two way video call. All other infrastructure are at par or better than anyone in the same league i.e. captives working out of India.  
2. Very stable with established processes. Any employee of the organization can rest assured that the benefits like flexibility to change teams within the organization after a given period of time will not be denied or frowned. It is a blessing to be in an organization where you can rest assured that the basics are already taken care of.
cons: 1. The management layer i.e Executive Directors and above. Nobody knows IT (except 1 or 2). Nobody knows domain (might be 10% does). They are where they are because they are the favorite of someone in power, most likely in USA. They try their level best to do nothing through their days to unsettle that equation. If you are looking for dynamic, strong leadership, look somewhere else. If you are looking for a bunch of old, has-been worker, stuck in the same team for 7 years, did not write any code or contribute anything to delivery for last 5 years, controlling your year end appraisal and increment, welcome to JPMC India.

review_title: Front office tech team - good work/life balance
pros: Relaxed atmosphere where you are judged on delivery rather than hours worked - bear in mind that for tight deadlines this can sometimes mean putting in the hours, but that is not the norm.  Friendly professional people, all trying to do their best.  Every one at my level and above are good at what they do and there is a general expectation that you maintain that standard, particularly with regard to the team reputation. Management is very hands off, happy for you to drive the tactical work via your relationship with the business teams.
cons: Your career path is in your own hands with no support or direction from management.  They paid well on joining, but no pay rises for last three years and bonus reduced last year across team despite mostly strong ratings at annual appraisals and company profits higher than ever.  Teams are highly distributed globally with no local management engagement.

pros:
401k  match is good - 100% match for the first 5% of your salary you contribute.

cons:
ZERO upward mobility.  It is possible to make lateral job moves around the company but never for a "next level" position. No raises for lateral moves, EVER - no matter what. 
They will shuffle execs around and say "This is an example of career mobility!"

In over 10 years with with the company, Have never seen anyone receive a "Promotion" that wasn't part of some HR rejiggering.   

1% salary raise one time in 5 years working for Consumer Bank division - with good/above average performance reviews.  2% bonus is what you will recieve unless in a sales role (Recruiters will outright lie about the bonus to entice you to accept a lower base) 

Employee Satisfaction scores are in the toilet.  Executives get spanked for it so they put together a few employee led task groups that are just for show of action.  They are ineffective.  
Main driver of low employee sat. scores are long hours for little pay, the results literally say Compensation is the issue.  But the employee focus groups are charged with finding any other dissatisfaction drive EXCEPT salary. Its not allowed to be salary.

pros: They don't hassle you for sales referrals, good benefits, nice people and management depending on which branch you get. Paid vacation, sick time and time off. They work with your schedule
cons:
If you're a teller, I hope you're in school working towards something greater because the pay as a teller is horrible. They no longer have  assistant branch manager positions (slowly getting rid of them) so they created a new position that does the exact same work an ABM did but for about 10k-15k less a year that is absolutely NOT worth the stress. In more than 5 years, I've gotten about a $1 raise.  And as far as moving up, being a lead teller operations specialist is about it, which is the new lower paid position they have put into place to cover their losses. Unless you want to be a branch manager, thats the other option but once again, other banks will pay you much more.
Oh, and wearing a uniform everyday is the worse.

review_title: They are what they claim to be.
pros:
It's true, they value their people a lot. The work culture is great, specially the Technology Analyst Program (TAP) that they have for college graduates. It is simply the best, and the reason for that is the amazing training team who make it possible. Loads and loads to learn, which you even get to apply every day at work.

Apart from that, it is interesting to know how a bank of such a size still persists to keep it's spot in the market. The applications have many levels of support, and they are pretty serious about it. Only because they value their clients a lot. Even the smallest change that you do, requires reviewing and approval. And plus there's this huge chunk of data that you have to deal with. It's fun writing softwares that manage this data, it's a whole frontier altogether.
cons: Like any other firm I suppose, there is dependency between teams. This gives rise to sort of a communication gap, specially if the teams are in different time zones. Sometimes you have to wait for the days, for something that might take you just a few hours.

pros:
Performance-driven culture does not punish those that provide consistent value as expected. You can get a lot of practice learning to articulate such value.

Diversity and teamwork are a respected value in most of the orgs, so that's cool. Awesome development resources for those that invest the time in their development plan. 

And misfits get handled promptly as "problems don't transfer" even during re-orgs. Individuals are given real options to stand up for themselves. 

Leadership has well-defined escalations paths. There is growing undercurrent of leaders focus on "what matters most" to find the "way forward"
cons:
If you don't have an MBA going to work here, I'd suggest getting a couple good management book or make good friends fast.

Mistakes with impact outside your department get magnified. Culture is unforgiving. "Adapt or die" is unspoken mantra. Lots of burnout for those that cannot self-regulate well.

People waste a lot of time navigating power channels to make improvements, and the number of "informing" networks is simply nauseating.

Still more work to do from incomplete merger integrations. "Making your boss look good" and "trust issues" are concentrated in some lines of business.

review_title: Good place to work for, very good pay and respectful management, but be ready for extremely long hours.
pros: Good compensation package and some of the smartest and best people in the industry. There was always good collaboration between each department, and managers are humble enough to listen to each and every employee as if all were managers. There was almost no way to tell that managers were above other employees, and despite treating others fairly, they also were able to lead by example. The environment though extremely professional, also had a casual air about it and that helped reduce some of the stress from an already extremely stressful job. It also seemed extremely easy to switch from one department from the other, such as from HR to trading access products on the equity derivatives floor. There were numerous meetings to review and praise each group about profit and success.
cons: Very long hours, and at times when work just piled on (Summer credit crunch) it seems that no one was really able to take a break. Some of the trading and marketing desks seemed to be understaffed as they would almost always have to work over 14 hours a day five days a week, which made middle office have to stay even longer.

pros: Good Place to Start if seeking long term temporary position. Compensation reflected work ethic and was very generous due to time spent. Superiors were willing to teach while working together on projects. Treated as an equal even though I was there as a temp upon leaving there were no hard feelings and I was well compensated due to time spent with multiple departments. Overall it is a positive work environment.
cons: The work was physically demanding at times. I would often have to work with more than one department at a time doing different duties which demanded my movement from different buildings until taking the initiative to organize a copy room from scratch which took away from my dedication to one department.  However having to build a copy area was an experience my supervisor saw fit as something I would be able to handle due too the training he gave me. This  leaving allowed me to learn how to multi-task in an order to get all my work done this position though temporary actually turned what I first thought was a Con into a Pro it is a fitting place for beginners and those in and fresh out of college.

review_title: Investment Bank is a solid place to work, need to be very politically savvy for the plum assignments
pros: I was exposed to a high volume of transactions (something recruiters typically like to see). The company gave me increasingly harder and more complex deals to look at as I became more experienced.  Their vacation policy was generous, I had the standard two week/yr previously and when I joined the investment bank it automatically became four weeks.  You will never be able to take that much vacation with the workload, but it does help if you are laid off (which I was) or need to take a leave of absence since you must use your vacation first. The bank also likes to keep up with technology, probably stemming from the top--it's a priority for Jamie Dimon.
cons: Its an investment bank so you will work long, long hours.  There is hardly any administrative support. The organization is flat and unless you are politically savvy, then you will toil in your cubicle. Further, I worked in a regional office so it is very difficult to make much headway when no one from senior management sees you face to face everyday.  I noticed that those who started at the same time, but worked in the NY main office did much better than those who worked elsewhere. There is a hyperfocus on containing costs and expenses, again, this being a priority of Jamie Dimon.

review_title: Used to be Great...but now going downhill !
pros:
Great people working in the lower 'worker bee' ranks and middle management.
Knowledgeable Staff, many have been in the company and know what to do and who to go to.
Good work life balance - depending on manager.
Great opportunities if you are willing to put in the effort.
Fantastic benefits & flexible packages.
Leading Technology
cons:
Lots of red tape and bureaucracy between teams and too many processes to get things done on time. 
If something goes wrong, there is too much of 'its not my teams issue' culture, always another teams fault.
People above middle management have lost touch and with middle management and completely detached with the 'worker bees'.
No work life balance - depending on manager.
Losing Key Staff due to relocation or redundancies

review_title: External Audit Coordinator (Business Credit / Field Exam)
pros:
Excellent Brand to be affiliated with.
Best to enter via the undergrad & graduate summer  internship programs.
Much to learn and aquire.
Great infrastructure.
Job stability.
cons:
JPMC has several lines of business that have split IDs, The Chase & JPMorgan brands. 
External Audit for large Commercial Loans has to balance both due to clients identifying w one vs the other.
Company HR has a very weird hidden metric regarding grade/salary level vs yrs of experience vs yrs of education, etc.
Better leaving the pack for 1-2 yrs to get promoted levels than staying internal.
National group w poor leadership.
Dept. Aging out, staffing wise; huge age divide which affects decision making and forward progress.
Project Managers that aren't qualified to hold the title; glorified secretaries for Managing Directors.
Not equipped to handle departmental staff conflicts & squabbles; old school vs new age
Remote work promise but at Manager's discretion
Constant firm wide realignment, so the dept is not sure who & which line of business it belongs/reports to... could be Chase Business Credit, Investment Bank, or Commercial Bank.
Has offices in NYC, Chicago, Ohio, Texas, and California, but not easy to move between locations.
Should focus on recruiting younger talent, avg. Dept age approx. 55 yrs.
Reputation as a Dept full of Lifers!

pros: Job requirements will usually be made clear, up front.  If you can keep your head down, fly below the radar and continue to do what is required of you, you will survive.  You may need to be flexible and willing to reinvent yourself, perhaps relocate, to avoid job loss as work is outsourced, moved to centralized locations, and jobs are cut.
cons: Large, slow bureacracy makes it difficult to make a true difference as an employee.  The company meets the letter of the law in dealing with its Employees, Customers and Shareholders, but all three groups of stakeholders are being treated with less and less consideration as the firm grows larger.  Employees in all areas of the company that I encountered are being forced to take "do more with less" to an extreme, as co-workers are cut and not replaced.  My impression is that the firm is paying less than it used to for the same work, requiring more hours and/or more work from each employee, and finding inventive ways to push higher-paid, longer-tenured employees out the door, to replace them with new, cheaper help.

review_title: Not a great company for women, with HR and management issues
pros: Global firm with opportunities to work with colleagues around the world
cons:
I would not recommend J.P. Morgan especially for minorities and women. The downsides observed are 
1) Not a lot of promotion opportunities for women compared with the other banks: women at Executive Director and Managing Director levels are only at 22%. In my specific product organization, there're only 2 women MDs who manage a very small number of direct reports. Women are also not treated the same as men. 

2) Promotion is purely relationship based - MDs are required to "sponsor" your promotion which translates into a relationship vs. merit based promotion policy; in addition, you can't apply for jobs at different levels even though you may be qualified - this is a hard HR policy across the firm. 

3) HR hotlines and management issues: various team members mentioned they experienced issues when reporting and escalating issues to HR -- HR staff either don't take any actions or take actions with minimum effort, which results in covering up issues for the management, and ignorance of serious employee concerns. 

In fact, in the annual employee survey, employees were not even asked to provide open comments, with the exception if the open feedback collected is regarding "if it's affecting you to complete your expected job functions" - this really shows the company's culture too.

review_title: Good work environment, but limited growth opportunities
pros:
Quality of co-workers is good. So you are not stuck due to incompetence of someone else (atleast not for long) as often happens in service industry.
If you have the right level of assertion and execution capabilities, you can get good visibility which you can utilize to get faster promotions.
cons:
If you are at non-management level, Increments will be getting tinier year after year; and if you have entered on lower level of salary band you will take years to reach a decent level. Strongly advice to enter only at higher levels to enjoy better raises and faster promotions. Else be prepared for a stagnated career.

Going towards the service industry way. Employees were once considered asset (maybe they are still considered so in few geographies). Now its a body shop. 

No career path. People are stuck doing same stuff with no visible career path.

No onsite opportunities.

Compared to service industry, the salary will only be 20% higher in most cases or atleast that will become the case in 2 years time once you join. In my opinion, service industry provides better career path, opportunities; though the base salary may be a tab lower than JPMC

review_title: Not a global company but just an American company with overseas operations. Cannot control the local offices.
pros: Well known company name and looks good on the resume. Possible mobility to other countries for your career but with low salary.
cons: Very american meaning non-US personals have some limitations going up the ladder as the global office keeps putting ny management at the top of regional heads making more layers in the matrix. Have seen some cases where asian  regional heads resign at the same time and leave one american management to do the job. The global office is more focused in europe and the states as thats where most revenues are from. Maybe china is the only asian market which gets some attention from the global office. Within jpmorgan group AM is the smallest and contributes less to the group. therefore, you tend to see better people working at IB side. Local offices get less pay and hard to get promoted as there is not much room for growth in the small local market.

review_title: Good people / hard to get things done
pros: The people I worked with were all great.  The project was challenging and the environment was good. Their Expert Engineer Program is excellent.
cons: Getting simple things done can involve a lot of effort. The company has centralized everything, so you end up dealing a lot with faceless teams spread all over the world who have no idea about what you are trying to do (and don't really care either).   One example, I tried to get a piece of software that was essential to my job (I was setting up a brand new team so nobody previously had need for this type of software). The request got bogged down initially in the request system (rejected with no explanation multiple times), then in getting approvals (dozens of them required, most people in the list having no idea why they are on there),  then in having legal review the license,  then in payment,  then after all that actually getting the software delivered took forever. All of these processes are separate, and you are expected to just figure everything out yourself. The teams don't coordinate and bounce you back and forth, and the internal apps to mange this are all comically bad. It took 8 months to get what I needed.  Anything that is non-standard is like this

review_title: May be a great place to work - not in my case
pros: Latest technologies, Pay is decent, Nice canteen and facilities, cab drops, company reputation.
cons:
Depending on the team, work-life balance can be horrible, like in my case. Never left office before 11 PM. 
Some work till 3 AM. HRs have no idea of work culture in a particular team. "Rarely you may have to stay a bit late" - is what they'd say before joining - Total BS.
Managers form opinion even before you've started delivering.  
Lots of bias towards certain employees. Some employees are always right, some are always wrong. You'll be ignored deliberately in meetings. Your efforts will be ridiculed if you're not liked.
Very unpredictable behavior from Manager. You get shouted for doing something one day, and for not doing the same thing other day.  
Reporting to multiple bosses - Each has their own agenda, mostly contradicting with each other. most of the time you get confused on what direction to take.
Too much bureaucracy - to get a simple job done, there is a lot of process and approvals involved. Most of times you feel that you're chasing processes than getting work done. 
If something is successful, your Manager takes credit, something goes wrong - you're responsible.
Too many meetings - most of them useless, you spend more than half day and most of your productive time in useless meetings.
There are many more, but that's it for now.

review_title: This is not your grandfather's JP Morgan
pros: Competitive salaries.  Resume builder.  Work from home available (if your manage approves it -- rare though).
cons: Heavy politics.  Lots of unnecessary red tape to navigate through in order to get things done (due to people justifying their existence).  Senior managers are clueless as to what really happens in the trenches.  Mid-management is typically a "boys club" and very hard to break into unless you know someone (hard work will not pay off otherwise).  Promotions are also political as management wants to limit the compensation pool.  Not very "senior" friendly -- once you reach a certain age it's amazing how quickly they try to get rid of you.   Don't think you will be working here for 30 years, unless you have managed to dodge the hurdles of management changes and you are able to maintain your network with senior management.  There is no loyalty here; unlike the JP Morgan of old --this IS Chase now (cut throat, budget-oriented environment all to make a buck at your expense).

review_title: Not a place for Quants over 25

Company efficiency is horrible. Your immediate manager will compete with their counterpart to see how late they can make their underlings stay. Within 2 weeks of starting, my outlook calendar had 6-7PM meetings daily out to the next 4 months. The meetings were pointless and only served to send to the organizer's superior that they were "on top of things."

The place is a mess and turnover was high. The result was everyone was new/bad at their jobs and combined with the disorganization, it made efficiency really low. They have 5 people doing a job that would be handled by one person in many banks. Upper management in New York often calls in to meetings and generally act like overgrown children to boss around underlings on pointless things.

review_title: The worst company I have ever worked in
pros: Bank has weathered financial crisis better than most
cons:
JP Morgan is by far the worst company I have ever worked in.
 
1.  Talents are wasted.  Qualified accountants are employed to perform daily system reconciliations which requires no accounting knowledge whatsoever.
 
2.  To do system reconciliations you need to build up knowledge of the specific JPM systems, which means to do your job properly you have to spend a lot of time building up non-transferable skills
 
3.  Focus of most roles are very narrow.  Staff are pigeon holed into doing a few specific things, and most people are happy to just follow the instructions and do not take ownership (or do not have enough knowledge to take ownership) when something goes wrong.  There have been so many times when I have heard "I just press the buttons" (or something similar)
 
4.  Management show no appreciation for staff.  They see nothing wrong with making staff work until midnight, on weekends or on public holidays and do not even say a "Thank you".  Yet, they have no problem sending around an email reminding everyone that the working day starts at 9am, and a number of people have been coming in a few minutes late.  
 
5.  Management are very petty.  As an example: In 2007 (the most profitable year for JPM before the credit crisis), the company asked staff to pay £15 if they wanted to go to the company Christmas party.  I mean, come on!  Even Greenpeace give their staff a free Christmas party!

review_title: Outsourcing is not an area of expertise
pros:
time off benefits are very good.

health benefits are average

will license staff or get other certifications relevant to the industry

locations in multiple US cities

some managers are open to remote work arrangements (varies by role and mgr - so ask during an interview)

Lots of open positions all the time (see cons for why)

culture allows for creative thinking

If you're very good at your job, not hard to shine among your peers (see cons for why)
cons:
benefits admin is a low margin business, so it's not uncommon to see expense mgmt via understaffing.  This leads to overloaded staff and high turnover.

it's a financial services firm, not a professional services one.  therefore there are internal barriers you won't find at other places.   JPM RPS  seems to be more about PR management than retention, expertise, or client feedback.

Growth through acquisition means that some dead weight comes with every deal and the managers don't address it.  Even heard an executive director in Overland Park say he would not fire anyone.  Weak!

Pay raises are non-existent or insulting  - they don't pay for performance.  Bonus program is completely arbitrary.

pros:
- some brilliant people work here
- if you are good at networking you can make some great life-long contacts
- global organization provides exposure to multiple cultures
- great for tarting a career; not for the long term
- really decent work/life balance
- Jamie is smart, a great leader; it's the 2nd and 3rd levels down that are super questionable
cons:
- several groups are led by inexperienced managers or ppl who don't have the right skillset
- nepotism is rampant
- internal politics are stifling; but it you can navigate them you'll be fine
- poor internal communication; i found out about things from ppl outside the company before I was notified
- outright lies: there would be no layoffs associated with the London Whale debacle...then 6-10 months later began the "restructuring". Though you can't directly associate with the incident, every dept was asked to make cuts and several volunteered instead of being forced
- no clear path on promotions; many clear lifers
- budgeting was a joke. Each year asked to put together a budget to match division strategy (what strategy?). You work with teams to design the right budget and marketing programs...then you'd get the same budget - 10%. Product executives would be annoyed by the waste of time. Why go through the exercise? Tell us what it is and we'll make decisions

pros: High end medical insurance, lots of activities, close connection with different regions, work life balance, many employee chaired committees for all kinds of activities.
cons:
JP Morgan arranged a volunteer activity in a school for students from dis-advantaged families in China. Volunteers' first task was to teach students to draw pictures by using coffee grounds. The school teacher requested the volunteers to encourage a student who was crippled by poliomyelitis. Volunteers discussed and planned to tell the student that his picture looks like an abstract painting and reward the student a pencil box. A legal executive director of JP Morgan China grabbed the picture and threw it into the rubbish bin, and told the volunteers the picture was a rubbish. Then she turned to the whole class of students, said loudly to all of them, "Although that student drew badly, let's still give him a pencil box because he is a disabled person, ok?"
The volunteers' second task was to teach students basic knowledge on constitution law, ask the students to take quizzes, and reward them pencils if they gave correct answers. The legal executive director of JP Morgan China always asked one particular student to answer questions and kept giving that student pencils. The school teacher interrupted her and requested her to give opportunities to other students. The legal executive director of JP Morgan China told the school teacher loudly and proudly, "intelligent person should always get more."

pros: Depending on the department you worked in, you could have a good work/life balance. The benefits are also good. How you are treated as an employee varies greatly depending on your manager and the division you work in
cons: You have no idea what your potential bonus can be and it also varies greatly per department.  They stack rank employees to determine bonus but if you have a higher salary, you will automatically be at the bottom, so you get a lower bonus.  The culture favors people who came from heritage Bank One.  Sr Leadership manages by fear.  If you came from WaMu you were treated like a loser because you must have been one or WaMu would not have failed.  I also had a manager that played favorites and micro-managed.  She'd give you a task Friday afternoon and on Saturday she'd be following up on why it wasn't completed yet.  My manager also feared senior leadership.  They also didn't care what time zone you were in.  I had to be on a call every Friday at 4:30am to give a 5 minute update on status.  Most days I had meetings at 5am or 6 am.  Like many former WaMulians, I was very happy to leave.

pros:

- Long working Hours (Come at your will, leave at Manager's will) . They would be happy if you join as bonded labor.
- Work culture sucks . Politics rocks !!!
- No stress on technology enhancement.
- Good practices are not followed at all .
- You don't have any choice. You will be assigned a task which you have to complete within specified time . You don't have any say.
- You can't enjoy your week ends . All deployments and prod-fixes happen in week-ends.
- You will be asked to login from home after 10PM in night .
- If you think you will be rewarded with good bonus, then you are wrong. Most people don't get good bonus , even zero . Hike doesn't exceed 5% .
- Hire and Fire policy works best . Every year, scores of people are fired, not because of performance, but cost-cutting.
Attention: == > 1. Don't Join AWM (Asset Wealth Management) or WM (Wealth Management) .
2. If at all, you somehow landed in AWM/WM, Don't join PAM/Mossaic/Account maintenance/KYC teams,
    because management of PAM team is horrible who knows nothing except advising resources to stretch
    day in and day out. Sometimes They ask you to work in multiple projects. They dont give good feedback and appraisal to her resources.
3. If you are very unlucky and landed in one of the AWM/WM teams, then at least check your direct manager's name and project name and seek feedback.

pros:
1) The biggest pro of working here is the environment. It is so relaxed and chilled out that you may not feel like you are working for one of the biggest financial institution.
2) I worked for almost 7 years and during that period had many managers to report to. All, except one, had the same motto, complete your work and enjoy.
3) Huge cafeteria with ample space to sit and eat with break-out areas on each floor where you can relax and enjoy a cup of tea or coffee.
4) Air conditioned cab services to drop you home.
cons:
1) As I mentioned in the pros, that except one manager all were very professional approach. This one guy ruined my joy of working there and was the reason for me quitting the job . Not sure if this counts as a con.
2) Salaries not upto market standards, but have heard that they have begun to give some pretty good raises over the past one year.
3) Public holidays are very limited (just 2 per year in the team where I worked). But they give plenty of other leaves to compensate.
4) The night allowances were pretty miserable.

review_title: Good work, Good pay but poor management.
pros:
The work you get is good, lot of technical challenges that helps in learning and growth.
All kinds of tools and application are available to try hands on and learn.
Salary and bonus are good.
No strict punch in and punch out hour count.
cons:
The company is bureaucratic and management is aristocratic. 
Management is mostly oblivious to employee growth and requirements and managers are simple too busy to please their managers to care for their reportees, there's no feedback taken for managers hence they are free to treat an employee the way they please and people are often threatened with their rating or "something bad" if they ask something management is uncomfortable with.
The management won't care for you unless you have spent around 3 years in company and it's then they try to fathom where you might be going.
Lot of irrelevant hierarchy one person can easily have local lead, a local manager an onsite lead and onsite manager and few other people  he reports too, he may not even know what kind of feedback is being shared about him, so at appraisal time ratings are very random and erratic.
